awd_titl_txt: Graduate Student Participation in National Workshops to Encourage Women's Engagement in Mathematics Research
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports graduate student participation at four workshops presented by the Association for Women in Mathematics (AWM) during major US mathematics meetings in 2016-2018. These meetings are the annual meeting of the Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics in 2016 (held in Boston, MA) and 2017 (held in Pittsburgh, PA), and the Joint Mathematics Meetings in 2017 (held in Atlanta, GA) and 2018 (held in San Diego, CA).  These Meetings Workshops will bring the rising women stars and current mathematical leaders together with graduate students and recent graduates from a variety of fields in pure and applied mathematics. By creating a rich intellectual community centered on shared research interests, the activities promise to generate new mentoring relations, new research collaborations, and increased activity in the associated research areas. Such relationships can lead to a lifetime of professional success. Moreover, these events at highly visible national meetings benefit the entire mathematical community by showcasing the excellent mathematical work done by women.

Each Meetings Workshop has a research focus derived from a prior AWM Research Collaboration Workshop, a week-long event where participants work together on open research problems. At the Meetings Workshops, leaders in each research field will introduce younger mathematicians to a deeper understanding of the field and its connections with their own work. Graduate students will, in turn, share their research during poster sessions and small group interactions. The research topics that will be highlighted in the next four workshops include Dynamical Systems with applications to Medical Problems;  Number Theory;  Numerical Partial Differential Equations; and Noncommutative Algebra. These topics span a broad spectrum of current mathematical problems, and will correspondingly enhance the future careers of many young women mathematicians.  For more information on the first two conferences, please see https://sites.google.com/site/awmmath/programs/workshops/SIAM-workshop and https://sites.google.com/site/awmmath/programs/workshops/jmm-workshop.  This award is jointly funded by the Infrastructure, Algebra and Number Theory, Mathematical Biology, and Computational Mathematics Programs within the NSF Division of Mathematical Sciences.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of the Association for Women in Mathematics is to encourage women and girls to study and to have active careers in the mathematical sciences, and to promote equal opportunity and the equal treatment of women and girls in the mathematical sciences. The AWM workshop is designed with the goal of increasing the visibility of women in mathematics by providing an opportunity for early-career women, including graduate students, to present their work at a national conference. Networking events facilitate interactions among graduate students, postdocs, faculty and other professional mathematicians. 

Financial support provided by the NSF was used to provide travel funding for graduate student to participate in workshops at four national meetings in 2016, 2017 and 2018: the annual Joint Mathematics Meetings (JMM) and the annual Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics (SIAM). The students were able to present research posters, attend the AWM special sessions, the AWM career panel, and participate in the AWM mentoring program and luncheon.

  • The AWM workshop at SIAM 2016 was held July 11-15 in Boston, MA on the topic "Dynamical Systems in Biology and Medicine", the topic of the WhAM! Workshop (Women in Applied Mathematics) held at the Institute for Mathematics and its Applications (IMA) in September, 2013. The career panel topic was about how to negotiate the mathematical community as a woman.
  • The AWM workshop at JMM 2017 was held January 4-7 in Atlanta, GA. The topic of the AWM Special Session was "Women in Number Theory", a follow up to the WINE and WIN3 Workshops held at Luminy and Banff in 2013 and 2014.
  • The AWM workshop at SIAM 2017 was held July 10-14 in Pittsburgh, PA. The topic of the AWM Special Session was "Numerical Partial Differential Equations and Scientific Computing", a follow up to the WhAM!2 Workshop held at IMA, August, 2014.
  • The AWM workshop at JMM 2018 was held January 10-13 in San Diego, CA. The topic of the AWM Special Session was "Women in Noncommutative Algebra and Representation Theory", a follow-up to the WiNART Workshop in Banff in 2016.

All four of the workshops had similar formats: research-focused special sessions, a panel discussion, a poster session for graduate students, and a luncheon. The research focus of each meeting drew from a topic from of one of the Research Collaboration Workshops for Women, a recent AWM initiative where women graduate students, postdocs, and more advanced women spend one week actively working on projects proposed by senior women in the field. The graduate student posters came from various research areas, but several were from the research focus of the special sessions. Attendance at the research focused special sessions aided graduate students in understanding the greater context for their research while connecting women graduate students immediately to the larger network of research-active women.

Intellectual Merit : 

These events brought together the rising women stars and current mathematical leaders from a variety of fields in pure and applied mathematics. By creating a rich intellectual community centered on shared research interests, the workshop activities generated new mentoring relationships, new research collaborations, and increased activity in those research areas.

Broader Impacts : 

Progress toward improving the situation for women in mathematics has stalled in recent years. According to the American Mathematical Society, the percentage of women among all mathematics PhD recipients in the US has hovered around 30% for the past 12 years, while the percentage of women among US citizens receiving PhDs has declined from a high of 38% in 2002-2003 to 28% in 2010-2011, rising to only 31.5% as of 2014

AWM activities work to address that lag by supporting women in their mathematical endeavors. The four workshop events supported by this grant promoted networking,  mentoring relationships, and research collaborations among women, especially those just beginning their careers. Such relationships can lead to a lifetime of professional success. Moreover, the events at JMM and SIAM benefited the entire mathematical community by showcasing the excellent work done by women.
